nodes.text: Machine learning can provide novel insights and practical opportunities to solve important challenges in reliability engineering and safety, improving prediction, diagnosis, decision-making, and accident prevention
Machine learning comprises supervised, unsupervised, semi-supervised, and reinforcement learning categories, each with distinct tasks and common models
Supervised ML methods are widely used for regression and classification in prognostics and health management, notably remaining useful life (RUL) estimation and fault classification
Empirical applications demonstrate ML for RUL and degradation prediction across domains (batteries, bearings, turbine tools, aircraft engines) using SVR, GPR, DNN, LSTM and other models
Unsupervised and semi-supervised ML, including clustering and anomaly detection, are effective for early fault detection and for leveraging abundant unlabeled data when labeled failures are scarce

Spacecraft telemetry and industrial examples show anomaly detection can identify contextual anomalies but often suffer high false positive rates requiring improved methods and deployment consideration

Deep learning architectures (CNN, RNN, LSTM, autoencoders, DBN, GANs) offer distinctive advantages for high-dimensional, nonlinear, and temporal reliability and safety problems by automatic feature extraction
Studies report deep models outperform shallow ML in anomaly detection, RUL prediction, and PHM tasks (examples: CNN for bearings, LSTM for spacecraft telemetry, deep autoencoders for flight data)
Reinforcement learning and deep reinforcement learning can address large-scale inspection, maintenance scheduling, and decision-making problems that are intractable for classical MDP/POMDP methods

Recent works demonstrate DRL for mobility robustness, condition-based maintenance planning for multi-component systems, and DRL-based sampling for structural reliability with superior performance to traditional methods

Practical limitations include uncertainty quantification, deployment considerations, false alarm rates, interpretability, computational cost, data scarcity, and potential publication bias favoring positive ML results
The authors identify priority future opportunities where ML can advance reliability and safety
Opportunity 1: improve uncertainty quantification and reduction, and address deployment issues to make ML predictions actionable and trustworthy
Opportunity 2: apply ML at fleet and system-of-systems scale for PHM and reliability, integrating transfer learning and systems engineering models
Opportunity 3: integrate ML with accident databases, safety management systems, and near-miss data to extract richer insights for accident and injury prevention
Opportunity 4: combine ML with wearable and sensor systems for predictive safety analytics and injury prevention in domains like elderly falls, occupational safety, and assisted maintenance

Opportunity 5: leverage advanced models such as deep Gaussian processes and generative adversarial networks for better uncertainty estimation, generative data augmentation, and high-dimensional reliability tasks
